section.para: Theodorus and Cornelis were going at each other hammer and tongues, oblivious to the audience they were attracting. The new batch of workmen who had been taken on in an effort to speed things up were looking on with some anxiety, somehow intuiting that they were the focus of the disagreement and hoping that it was not going to lead to their dismissal with the consequent return to poverty and idleness. The old hands, however, just shrugged and rolled their eyes, barely pausing in their work. The tension between the two bosses had been building for some time culminating in a storm that would blow itself out before the end of the day. No need to worry, they advised the new men, just get on with your tasks.

It was, indeed, the arrival of the gang of new workers which had been the catalyst for the rather public venting of anger by the two overseers. They and their attendant problems were not the direct cause but consequent upon the approaching deadline for completion of the house which had been imposed by the Burgermeester. Marcellus Bisdom van Vliet had his heart, and his gilders, set on being able to celebrate his 50 year anniversary as Burgermeester of Haastrecht from the new house which had been commissioned specially for this occasion. The whole village had involved themselves in grand plans to honour him, suddenly making concrete the date by which the house should be finished.
This date was August 23rd 1976 - and there was such a lot left to do!

Much had been accomplished so far. Once the old house had been raised to its foundations, these had needed strengthening with new brickwork onto which the heavy timbers for the floor joists had been laid. Once the shell of the house had been built using thousands upon thousands of bricks it was time for the hard work of lifting and fitting the roof beams and trusses. The complex structure and area of the upper floor of the house made for a cats cradle of necessary wooden supporting structure which would be strong enough to take the Fries flat pan tiles of the roof. Meanwhile windows and doors were created and installed so that the building was weather proof and the interior work could begin.

All of the heavy construction materials had to be brought along the river by barge. The craft were sized to fit the confines of the waterways they operated on and were each crewed by a single family who lived on board. To maximize cargo space the living quarters were squeezed into the stern with cooking, eating, washing and sleeping all vying for space. Boards laid across the space served as beds and had to be taken away before the day's domestic activities could begin. Families with many children crowded together so disease was rife, as was malnutrition as parents struggled to fill mouths on their meagre income. Yet more babies easily came along but many died before they were old enough to walk. It had not been unusual to see the wife harnessed to a line ashore pulling the laden barge whilst her husband, worn out by the effort of lading and discharging cargo, stayed on board and steered from the tiller at the stern. Wind and current were not always favourable to these folk and horse power often beyond their means. These were weatherbeaten and hard-muscled folk, old before their time with lives often prematurely ended by illnesses which the doctors were too busy or disinterested to diagnose or treat, so the register of burials simply recorded their deaths as due to "exhaustion".

At least the carters who then brought the finer timber for interior work and all the necessaries for plasterwork and decorative finishes could spend the night with a roof over their heads, however mean a hovel they called home. They worked their horses hard but Paulina, who had a strong interest in matter equine, made sure that the animals were not ill treated or underfed. Some said that she showed more care for the welfare of the horses than their handlers.

Since Theodorus could not manage the building work and do the plasterwork himself, he had engaged FPC Schild to undertake the massive amount of skilled work in plastering the ceilings and all the decorative plasterwork of the interior. Herein lay the source of the argument between Theodorus and Cornelis. The plasterwork was falling behind schedule because other work, which needed to be done first, had not been completed. Hence the influx of new workers. However, both Theodorus and Cornelis had laid claim to these men and set them on competing tasks. Given the tense atmosphere created by time pressure, it was perhaps understandable that the conflict erupted into an angry exchange. Once some steam had been let off, both men were able to regain their equilibrium and their usually excellent working relationship was able to reassert itself. The next time workers looked in their direction they saw the two men briefly embracing each other then shaking hands with smiles on their faces.

Then Theodrus and Cornelis shut themselves up in the makeshift office and let it be known that they were only to be disturbed in case of dire emergency. Any knocks on the door or timid calls were ignored. Their agreed strategy was to take an imaginary walk through the house, compiling lists of unfinished work in each room as they went. They also had a draft of the celebrations planned for the day of Marcellus's 50th anniversary as Burgermeester .

The obvious place to start was at the ingang, or entrance, and the vestibule beyond it. Placed in the centre of the the seven bays on the ground floor, the large, sturdy wooden door was already in place. Although it opened as a single door, a central column decorated with vines and grapes gave the impression of double doors. Symmetrical panels were glazed and decorated with wrought ironwork. Above and below each inset glass were carved panels, oblong below and circular bosses topped with semi-circular arches above. The rich colour of the wood and the multi-faceted carvings were pleasing to the eye and the whole was clearly designed to signal the protection it offered to the valuable contents which would eventually be contained within. Cornelis was proud of the skill he had exhibited in creating it and Theodorus thought this was rightly so.

But, they couldn't linger in admiration as there was a long way to go and both agreed that the impressive entry needed no improvement. Once inside, an entrance hall led up to the doorway into the gang, or inner hall, marking the transition from the public areas of the house to the family's private quarters. The public rooms were reached through doors leading off either side of the vestibule, one to a small salon on the left and one to a reception area on the right. In order to create the impression of symmetry, two false doors opposite the real ones, had been created with a central bay of plasterwork between them. Since this was the first impression visitors, not to mention Marcellus, would have it needed to show how important and wealthy the occupants of the house were. The decoration of the vestibule was, therefore, designed to provide an opulent impression but as a backdrop for the displays of valuable items and family crests destined to be placed there. So, whilst the ceiling rose, cornicing and the headers above the doors involved complex plaster mouldings which had been delicately painted in muted creams, the central panels were relatively plain with a touch of blue in places to set off the blue of the Chinese plates destined to be hung nearby. A marble floor provided the finishing touch to this relatively small but hugely important space.

The first room off the vestibule was the spreekkamer, or reception room. This would be where the maid who answered the door would take visitors to wait whilst she conveyed messages to and from the occupants of the house. Tradespeople would wait here to be paid and more important callers be divested of their outerwear before being admitted to the grote salon through the far door. A relatively plain room, then. Even so, it was yet to be finished as the expensive red flock wallpaper from England, chosen as a foil for the gilt framed paintings destined to be displayed against it, remained to be hung. Again, concerns about keeping the decoration clean came to the surface as flock wallpaper was notorious for attracting dirt. Since the guests admitted to the house for Marcellus's celebration were by invitation only, it was agreed that the completion of this room could be assigned a low priority and it was sealed off.

The same could not be said of the kleine salon through the left hand door off the vestibule. This was where Marcellus planned greet important political and business visitors and provide them with refreshments. An opportunity to make an impression which was too good to pass up so a suite of fashionable, expensive furnishings had been commissioned from Horrix of Den Haag, who made furniture for the King's house. Unlike the light, bright vestibule, the palette of the kleine salon darkened to for the ornate fireplace in black and cocoa brown for the walls. Deep creams and gold decorating the ceiling with its complex cornicing and fine ceiling rose from which a huge crystal chandelier was destined to cascade and glitter with candlelight or, on a good day, sunlight through the single window. Without the glittering chandelier and rich red of the upholstery and carpet, the room Theodorus and Cornelis were considering would have seemed dull were it not for the opulence of the plasterwork with its detail picked out in gold. Theodorus had minutely inspected these mouldings and was pleased with their execution. Another room they could agree was as finished as they could make it.

There were two doors off the kleine salon, one to the kantor, or office, at the front of the house and the other through into the gang. The latter was envisaged as to be used only by family and their servants and was now sealed off on the gang side. As was the doorway at the end of the vestibule. Now that all the work in the rooms at the front of the house which were to be used for the celebration had been done, the challenge was to keep it in pristine condition despite the mess being created by work in progress in the rest of the house. The opening out of the vestibule had been built to double thickness to accommodate two doors, one after the other, to symbolise its gate-keeping importance. To create a further barrier, provision had been made for a heavy curtain to span the width of the wall at the end of the vestibule thus concealing the entry to the domestic area beyond. For now, a temporary curtain had been hung here then both doors closed with the door on the family side sealed to shield the completed rooms from the dust and grime beyond. Use of the front door had been banned with everything and everyone coming and going through either the kitchen or garden room entrances.

Now the difficulties for Theodorus and Cornelis started. The gang was the hub of the house so still constantly in use by men working on the upstairs rooms yet time needed to be devoted to getting it ready for the grand event in August. This meant that all of the upstairs rooms which would be needed had to be given priority now so that they, too, could be sealed off whilst the central gang , trappenhuis, or staircase, and witte overloop, or white landing, were decorated. Then, working forwards, the ground floor family rooms must be completed, not to mention laying the groundwork for a working kitchen. All of this must be made ready in time for carpets to be laid, curtains hung, furniture placed, and all the many objects put on display. The only slight relief to this immense schedule of work was the decision by the family not to use part of the house. Paulina and her husband would be returning to their own house to sleep so the upstairs suite of rooms behind the carefully installed witte bovenportaal, or white screen and door, would not be needed. Also, since Marcellus was not the host but the guest of honour, the formal grote salon and eetkamer, or dining room, intended as function rooms would not be needed either. Already these rooms had been tidied and cleaned with the workmen redeployed to other parts of the house.

The situation which had been the trigger for the heated exchange between Theodorus and Cornelis earlier in the day now had to be addressed. The area of the house into which a full compliment of existing men plus the new workers drafted in that day had to operate was drastically reduced. The men themselves had instituted a system of entering by the kitchen door and exiting through the garden room door after several collisions and hold ups had frustrated tempers and damaged goods. This had not solved all of their issues as conflicts over who was doing what and where had proliferated. Theodorus recognised that he needed to manage the situation by allocating specific jobs to men and making sure that they were making due progress, reviewing the whole effort on at least a daily basis and adjusting deployments as necessary. He needed Cornelis to contribute to the identification of what needed to be done and to apply his knowledge of the men's capabilities to their allocation. The two men needed to be sure that they didn't contradict each other in directing the work yet dividing the overseeing between them to keep things in manageable proportions.

Theodorus was to take charge of the plasterwork and Cornelis the woodwork, that much was easy to decide as it played to their specialities. How to apportion the painters needed some consideration as both plasterwork and woodwork needed painting. However, there was painting and then there was painting. Applying base coats of paint required minimal skill. Colouring large areas of plain plaster on walls and ceilings required enough skill to give an even finish. Similarly smaller but plain sections of woodwork, such as doors and skirtings. Then there was carved wood and simple plaster mouldings needing care but not the skilled brushwork of intricate carvings and mouldings, especially where a steady hand and narrow brush were involved. Then there were the special techniques involved in imitating marble and different types of wood. These later stages of decoration needed carefully arranged drying times to cope with the application of different colours and finishes.

The planned use of rooms in the house during Marcellus's day of celebration was to begin with entry by the front door, passing through to the vestibule and from thence into the kleine salon where refreshments were to be served. When the Burgermeester was called to join the celebrations in his honour, he and his guests would pass through to the gang (making use, if necessary, of the modern toilet with its wooden casing wide enough to accommodate the ladies' vast skirts, marble walls and flushing bowl), ascend the trappenhuis to the witte overloop and from there into a small room that led out onto the balcony above the front door where Marcellus would stand to view the entertainments. Since the balcony itself was quite small, guests could also view proceedings from one of the large windows from a narrow gallery above the staircase. These areas of the house had to be ready in time and completed to the highest possible standard to honour Marcellus. Also, the burgermeester needed to be sure that his guests were sufficiently impressed in order to vindicate his decision to build a new house.

Out of the eyes of all but his closest family (and servants), the Burgermeeseter's private chambers led off the witte overloop through a frosted glazed door and screen, white on one side to match the entrance to Paulina's quarters opposite and brown on the other to follow the theme of Marcellus's rooms. Beyond this entrance lay a central hall the eponymous bruine overloop or brown hall. A door on the left leading towards the front of the house gave into Marcellus's bedroom and thence to his dressing room and the innovation of a bathroom. It was expected that Marcellus would spend at his first night here following his anniversary celebrations so these rooms also needed to be prepared to at least as high a standard as the areas of the house on general view. This was the most challenging part of the whole construction project, especially the bedroom where the Burgermeester had given his taste for the trappings of position and wealth full rein.

The imposing grey and red marble fireplace ensemble filled the space between floor and ceiling in the centre of the west wall. The ornate carvings of the sections above and below the mirror had survived relocation without cracks, chips or any more significant damage thanks to careful packing in fine cotton gauze, straw and sacking before being crated up. The less ornate sections had also been wrapped and crated in straw, but this had been a simpler task. The huge mirror with its curved shaping top and bottom had been similarly stored with great care, as had its delicate wooden mounting frame. Everyone concerned with installing the whole ensemble in its new location breathed a sigh of relief when this had been safely accomplished. Only one alteration had been required being the relatively straightforward job of taking a bit off the bottom of the pillars either side of the fire grate which had originally been taller and, some said, in better balance with the mirror section.

Cornelis Straver and his team of craftsmen could then finish installing the Mahogany wood paneling which Marcellus had commissioned. He had specified that all of the woodwork be in the 18th Century French Regency style, which had sent Cornelis scurrying off to France on a visit to the grand palaces of Verssailes and Fontainbleau to see for himself the sort of thing Marcellus had in mind. The delicate, curving shapes of the panels which edged the ceiling, rather than plaster cornicing, were something different from the rest of the house and presented Cornelis with an enjoyable challenge to his skill. Theodorus might have felt he got off lightly as the plasterwork in this chamber consisted of one, large and very smooth area on the ceiling and another small oval above the entry door. However, he then had the nightmare of finding a artist who was more than competent to execute the swirling skies and cavorting angels which continued the French theme on these flat areas of plaster. It was something of a relief that the plain wall areas inside their rectilinear wooden frames were more simply decorated. in plain, dark green with delicate, gold leaf tracery borders.

Not only had Marcellus given himself a stylish bedroom but also the luxury of a separate dressing room, the only one in the house. As was the bathroom leading from it, equipped with running hot and cold water and a zinc bath tub. The hot water had to be pumped up from the well under the kitchen terrace and heated in a geyser. The cold water was collected rainwater from the roof then held in a reservoir tank in the attic above. This arrangement gave sufficient pressure to work the taps and toilet flushes. He had done himself proud but not extended his largess to the quarters for his daughter and her husband, which were more conventional although they could not be describes as spartan by any stretch of the imagination. Nor were the meeting room and guest bedroom beyond which were accessed through the door off the bruine overloop towards the back of the house as luxurious as Marcellus's chambers, although he had insisted that the family crests were prominent in the decor.

On a more domestic note, the downstairs huiskamer where Marcellus and his family could sit and could take their meals once he was in residence, needed to be available for use. Since the celebration was to be in late August and some further weeks of fine weather were anticipated, the adjacent tuinkamer, or garden room, leading through huge, glass doors to a covered terrace and riverside garden beyond should be tidied for use by restless guests. By the end of their deliberations, Thoedorus and Cornelis had produced a daunting schedule of work and were rather down hearted to realise that they would not be able to rest on their laurels after the celebrations as much would still remain to be done and with the added complication of the master being in residence from time to time when not away on business or political involvement. Noise and mess would need to be kept to a minimum when Marcellus was home.
